comments.body: Can we also delete `target/scala-library` afterwards? Or maybe create this in a temporary directory?

Dowloading+unzipping takes a while to run and if it was deleted on every run then that would slow when running this multiple times locally. We only unzip `src/library` so it's not that bloated. I prefer to keep the directory.
ðŸ‘
@sjrd Is there a better way to do this?

> Here's my second best guess, but it doesn't work due to some reason

That's because `CrossVersion.binary` is a `def` which returns a new instance of `CrossVersion` every time, and in sbt 0.13.x, `==` is useless on `CrossVersion`s (it's equivalent to `eq`).

There is no elegant way to test the platform of a project in the most general case. The closest you can get is testing for the presence (or absence) of `scalajs-library` or `nativelib` in the `libraryDependencies` of the project.

Alternatively, in your own build, you could define your own very simple `lazy val platform = settingKey[String]` and configure it to your liking.

You could also test whether `thisProject.value.id` (or whatever it's called) ends with `"JVM"`, `"JS"` or `Native`.

And I'm sure you can invent other creative ways to do it.
Thanks for the swift response!

So, `semanticdb3Native/nativeLink` works great now thanks to SÃ©bastien's fix to sbt-crossproject and Denys's fix to Scala Native.

However it looks like we need help again. It seems that `semanticdb3Native/publish` misbehaves by publishing artifacts with wrong the target prefix. Here's a reproduction:

```
$ git clone https://github.com/xeno-by/scalameta.git
$ cd scalameta
$ git checkout repro/crossproject
$ sbt 'semanticdb3Native/publishLocal'
...
[info] 	published semanticdb3_2.11 to /Users/eburmako/.ivy2/local/org.scalameta/semanticdb3_2.11/3.0.0/poms/semanticdb3_2.11.pom
[info] 	published semanticdb3_2.11 to /Users/eburmako/.ivy2/local/org.scalameta/semanticdb3_2.11/3.0.0/jars/semanticdb3_2.11.jar
[info] 	published semanticdb3_2.11 to /Users/eburmako/.ivy2/local/org.scalameta/semanticdb3_2.11/3.0.0/srcs/semanticdb3_2.11-sources.jar
[info] 	published semanticdb3_2.11 to /Users/eburmako/.ivy2/local/org.scalameta/semanticdb3_2.11/3.0.0/docs/semanticdb3_2.11-javadoc.jar
[info] 	published ivy to /Users/eburmako/.ivy2/local/org.scalameta/semanticdb3_2.11/3.0.0/ivys/ivy.xml
[success] Total time: 11 s, completed Feb 5, 2018 9:46:27 PM
```

@densh @sjrd Do you guys have an idea what could go wrong here?
Mystery solved: https://github.com/scalameta/scalameta/pull/1263/commits/21c5568cb0a32bb8c42ef5dc798e273e93dd7a14. @olafurpg Do you remember why we added this to the build?

comments.body: Are these the usual SNAPSHOT releases, which make sbt do updates like crazy, or there's something special about them, since we seem to be publishing them to Sonatype releases?
it's possible to configure sbt to treat -SNAPSHOT versions like normal versions, we never overwrite an old release because every merge has a unique commit that is included in the version number.
`plz $ciScalaVersion test` should do this for you ;) but I don't mind as long as it works!
How about `semanticdbScalacLibrary`?

semanticdbScalac is better IMO since it matches the directory name and I run `semanticdbScalac/test` from the console all the time (which is already too long IMO), writing `Library` on top is just annoying.
Fair enough. lgtm.

@olafurpg This breaks scalatex. Do you have any idea why? To reproduce:
```
sbt readme/doc
```

I opened https://github.com/lihaoyi/Scalatex/pull/52 and published a pre-release of scalatex to our bintray repo with that fix. We can use the pre-release until the official scalatex is out

```scala
// project/plugins.sbt
resolvers += Resolver.bintrayIvyRepo("scalameta", "sbt-plugins") // only needed for scalatex 0.3.8-pre
addSbtPlugin("com.lihaoyi" % "scalatex-sbt-plugin" % "0.3.8-pre")
// build.sbt
resolvers += Resolver.bintrayRepo("scalameta", "maven") // under sharedSettings
```

comments.body: This line will fail if the main Scala version becomes 2.12, the scripted test depends on a 2.11 Scala version.
Why do we need this project at all?
Scalafix will depend on this project to construct an offline mirror. See https://github.com/scalacenter/scalafix/issues/100 for why scalafix can't depend on scalahost-nsc directly.
Also, paradise will depend on this project. At the moment, `addCompilerPlugin(paradise)` enables scalahost-nsc as well.

comments.body: Nice!
Btw how about a newline after this lazy val?
Done.
The publish task would hang on this line waiting for a username/password combo to be typed into the repl.
Can there be situations when tests work on the JVM and don't on JS?

Absolutely. For example, if you use `java.io.File`.

However, I left JS out because it's slow, see https://github.com/scala-js/scala-js/issues/2827 Sometimes, incremental can take 3-4 minutes to link before running. The cause seems to be that the Scala.js linker struggles with inlining the thousand `test` method calls to Scalatest. I suggest we leave this for the CI server to catch.
Same about `in`. These are supposedly idiomatic uses of the SBT DSL copied from the official documentation.

The official sbt docs also do
```scala
val foo = (project in file("bar").
  settings(...)
```

I'm strongly against infix application with multiple arguments since they can be hard to parse in my head. Regular Term.Apply is easier to read and it scales more nicely for additional arguments/chained calls. For example, the old `) dependsOn (common)` infix usage made it annoying to append another `.addPlugins (ScalaJSPluginb)` line at the end. For uniformity, I refactored all `in` calls to non-infix. Are you OK with keeping this?
I don't have a strong opinion. My only serious concern now is familiarity for newcomers.

comments.body: Same question as for `sonatypeCredentials`

The reason I refactored the build so much is because the crossProject changes made some settings evaluate twice or three times on build reload. While moving things around, I got weird compiler errors when around `Def.taskDyn` which I believe are attributed to being inside the `:=` macro. Even if this is only called once I think it's clearer to move it outside of the long `publishableSettings` sequence. 

I can move it back if you want. I honestly think there's way to much logic in this build.sbt which should be refactored into an sbt plugin, but that's for another PR.
I suggest we deduplicate this with https://github.com/scalameta/scalameta/blob/d38a0f9cd5e58373967d31e2a9ebe1ee67662690/build.sbt#L50-L51.
I reused noPublish in scalametaRoot: https://github.com/scalameta/scalameta/pull/753/files#diff-fdc3abdfd754eeb24090dbd90aeec2ceR24
Nice!
